What is Cryptography?

  1. Three Main Goals:
    1. Confidentiality: Preventing adversiries from reading our data.
    2. Integrity: Preventing attackers from altering our data. (regardless of its privacy)
    3. Authentication: Proving who created a given message or document.
  2. The Set Up:
    • Who’s involved:
      1. Alice: Sender.
      2. Bob: Receiver.
      3. Eve: Eavesdropper.
      4. Mallory: Manipulator.
    • Goals:
      1. Attackers Goal: Any Knowledge on besides a bound on it’s length.
      2. Defenders Goal: Ensure attakcer has no reason to think any is more likely than any other.

        Where .

    • Current Situation:
      1. Eve’s Capabilities:
        • No knowledge of the key .
        • Recognition of Success.

          Eve can tell if she fully (NOT PARTIALLY) recovered .

      2. The key :
        • Assume is selected completely randomly.
        • For a -bit key, any is equally likely.

  3. Terminology:
    1. Plaintext : The message to be sent.
    2. Cyphertext : The encrypted message that is sent.
    3. Key :
    4. Encryption Function : A function of the message and the key that outputs the cyphertext.
    5. Decryption Function :

  4. Types of Attacks:
    1. Cyphertext-only Attack:
      • Eve sees every instance of .
      • Eve knows some partial information (Variant).

        e.g. message is in English.

    2. Known Plaintext:
      • Eve knows part of and/or entire other ’s.
    3. Chosen Plaintext:
      • Eve gets Alice to send ’s of Eve’s choosing.
    4. Chose Cyphertext:
      • Eve tricks Bob into decrypting some of her choice and he reveals something about the result.
    5. Combination of all above:
      • Idealy, we would like to defend against this.
  5. Symmetric Key Encryption:
    When both the sender and receiver have the same key to encrypt and decrypt.
  6. Independence Under Chosen Plaintext Attack game (IND=CPA):
    • Eve is interacting with an encryption “Oracle”: The Oracle has an unknown key .
    • Eve can provide TWO seperate chosen plaintexts of the same length: Oracle will randomly select one to encrypt with the unknown key; the game can repeat.
    • Eve’s Goal: To have a better thatn random chance of guessing which plaintext the Oracle selected.

      Variations include the Orcale always selecting the first or the second.

    • To be Independent under Chose Plaintext: Eve must not be able to achieve her goal.
  7. Kerckhoffs Principle:
    1. Cryptosystems should remain secure even when the attakcer knows all the internal details.

      Don’t rely on security by 0bscur!ty.

    2. Key should be the only thing that must stay secret.
    3. It should be easy to change keys.

Caeser Ciphers

  1. ROTK and ROT-K:
    ROTK is an encryption function that takes each letter in and ‘rotates’ it $K$$ positions (with-wrapping) through the alphabet.
    ROT-K is a decryption function that takes each letter in and ‘rotates’ it $26-K$$ positions (with-wrapping) through the alphabet.
  2. Attacks on Caesar Ciphers:
    1. Brute-Force: try every possible value of k.
    2. Deduction: (known plaintext) Analyze letter frequencies - (chosen plaintext) Guess possible words.
  3. Enigma: Uses Caesar Ciphers but with a new key for each letter.

n-time Pads

  1. The XOR function:
  2. One-Time Pad:
    • We use a different key for each message M.
      • Different = Completely Independent.
    • Make the key as long as M.
    • .

    • Proof of security:
      Since K is random and independent, all possible bit-patterns for C are equally likely and the attacker cannot know anything about the system even from random text.
      Thus, observing a given C does not help Eve narrow down the possibilities whether Alice chose M’ or M’’.

    • Issues:
      1. Key-Generation: Need truly Random, Indepndent keys. Those are very very difficult to generate.
      2. Key-Distribution: Need to share keys as long as all possible communication.
  3. Two-Time Pads:
    • Reusing a key K one more time.
    • Alice sends C = E(M,K) and C’=E(M’,K).
    • Eve Obseves and computes .
    • Now, Eve knows everything about M’.
    • Thus, it is insecure.

Modern Encryption

  1. Block Cypher:
    • A function .
    • [For a fixed ] , denoted by .
    • Properties:
      1. Correctness: is a bijective permutation function.
      2. Efficiency: computable in microseconds.
      3. Security: For unknown , “behaves” like a random permutation.
  2. Data Encryption Standard (DES):
    • Designed in the Seventies.
    • Block Size 64 bits, Key size 56 bits.
    • Tweaked by the NSA.
  3. Advanced Encryption Standard (AES):
    • 20 years old, Standarized 15 years ago.
    • Block size 128 bits.
    • Key size 128, 192, 256 bits.
    • Assumed (but not proven) secure.
  4. Analysis on Brute-Forcing:
    • possibilities.
    • CPU capacity keys/second keys/sec.
    • Thus, we will need seconds, or approximately, trillion years.
  5. Drawbacks of Block Ciphers:
    • Block Ciphers can only encrypt messages of a certain size.
      • If is smaller, then just pad it.
      • If is larger, then repeatedly apply block cipher.

Modern Block Ciphers

  1. Electronic Code Book Mode(ECB):
    • Simplest Block Cipher mode.
    • Split the message into b-bit blocks .
    • Each block is enciphered independently, separate from the other blocks .
    • Since the key is fixed, each block is subject to the same permutation.

    • Issues:
      • Not IND-CPA
      • Thus, the relationship between the plaintext is reflected in the cyphertext.
  2. Building a better Cipher:
    1. Ensure blocks incorporate more than just the plaintext to mask relationships between blocks:
      1. Include elements of prior computation.
      2. (OR) Include positional information.
    2. Add initial Randomness:
      1. Prevent encryption scheme from determinism revealing relationships between messages.
      2. Introduce initialization vector (IV).

        IV is a public nonce, a use-once unique value: Easiest way to get one is generate it randomly

  3. CBC Encryption:
    :
    • Algorithm (Encryption)
      • If b is the block size of the block cipher, split the plaintext in blocks of size .
      • Choose a random IV (do not reuse for other messages)
      • Define .
      • The ith ciphertext block is given by .
      • The ciphertext is the concatenation of the initial vector and these individual blocks: .
    • Algorithm (Decryption)
      • Take the out of the ciphertext.
      • If is the block size of the block cipher, split the ciphertext in blocks of size .
      • The ith plaintext block is given by .
      • Output the plaintext as the concatenation of .
    • Properties:
      • Widely used.
      • Security: If no reuse of nonce, both are provably secure (IND-CPA) assuming the underlying block cipher is secure.
      • REusing the voids IND-SPA but is not terrible.
    • Issues:
      • Sequential encryption; we can’t parallelize encryption.
      • Must finish encrypting block before starting .

        But you can parallelize decryption

  4. CTR Mode:
    We avoid the issue of not non-parallizable ciphers by by encrypting a counter initialized to IV to obtain a sequence that can now be used as though they were the keys for a one-time pad:
    namely, and .

    Uses the encryptor for decrypting.
    CTR mode is a Stream Cipher.

    REusing the no more security.
  5. CFB Mode:
    • Properties:
      • Since the encryption is XORed with the plaintext.

        It is more convineant than CBC since it can end on a “short” block without a problem.

      • Similar security properties as CBC mode:
        1. Sequential encryption, parallel decryption.
        2. Same error propagation effects.
        3. Effectively the same for IND-CPA.
      • Worse than CBC if you reuse the .
